context: Commentary WHILE GLOBALISATION fatigue seems to set in, protectionism is emerging.
The question that needs to be asked is what is the trend underlying this phenomenon and how Asia should respond to it.
Since the World War II, free trade has been the cor nerstone of the world economy.

The establishment of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) in 1995 as well as numerous economic partnership and free trade agreements have promoted free trade based on the concept of comparative advantage.
Institutionalisation of trade and advancement of information technology brought the w orld ever closer together.
‘New Engine’ Getting Old? On the other hand, the postwar period required a ne w engine for the world economy to rebuild the nations devastated by the war.
Meanw hile, Germany and Japan have revived their manufacturing industries running trad e surplus against the United States, which they invested in US treasury securities.
The US was a major crude oil exporter until the 1970s.
When oil production declined, the US became increasingly dependent on oil from th e Middle East.
In turn, the oil producing countries invested their trade surplus in the US treasury securities over the coming decades.
Awash with the US dollar, the Bretton Woods system became unsustainable by 1973 and led to the twin deficit during the Reagan admin istration during the 1980s.
Still, the growth of financial markets backed by the US dollar continued to support the expanding international trade and world economy in the 1990s and 2000s.

US Turns to Protectionism The recycling of the US dollar has run its course while major central banks have taken a series of monetary easing policies in response to the global financial crisis in 2008.

The resulting low-interest rate environment and sur ging oil price encouraged investment into the oil industry, leading to the US shale revolution in 2011 and pushing its oil production above 1970 level.
The rise in the US oil production could contribute to reduction not only in trade deficit but also in the US treasury issuance, thus affectin g the world.
The US can now become self-sufficient in energy, reduce its debt issuance, and revive its manufacturing industry.
In other words, the US needs less free trade and mo re protectionism.
However, free trade remains crucial for other countries, especially those which mainly export or import oil.
This contradiction of benefits resulted in growing tension between policies of the US and its major trading partners.
However, it is not necessarily a bad thing.
The US government debt burdens future generations and the reduction of it is a national m andate.
On the other hand, major foreign US treasury securities holders such as Chin a and Japan can reduce holdings of these assets that sometimes even incur negative returns in their own currency terms.
The rest of the world can also become less a ffected by the US monetary policies.
Challenges to the World These changes will create new challenges.
First, the rise of the US interest rate means repat riation of the dollar circulating in the world, leading to lower liquidity.
Hence, the world needs to reduce its dependency on the dollar in trade and finance.
Secondly, global s upply chains need to adjust to the new US economy, which tries to revitalise manufactu ring industries.
Third, most countries will see their export to the US decline as the US enters trade wars.
These new challenges urge the world to adjust to a new form of international trade and to a multi-currency regime.
New wisdom and commitments are required to navigate the world economy to a new direction, which is difficult as we are bound by co nventional wisdom.
The hollowing out of the manufacturing industries in the US has m ade its society more vulnerable and allowed for racist sentiments to revive.
The feelings of despair in the Rust Belt were not s hared by the elites in the East Coast, who have promoted globalisation.
Donald Trump liste ned to the people who felt left out.
Contrary to being erratic or a racist, he may actually be gearing the US towards the new world.
How Should Asia Response? Asia needs to adjust to the protectionism of the US by introducing appropriate and effective counter measures.
More fundamentally, Asi a must 1) rebuild international trade via promotion of regional integration and 2) reduce dependency on the dollar.
To promote regional integration, countries need to harmonise regulations and standards in trading, banking, and accounting to cr eate larger markets.

Free trade agreements such as Comprehensive and Progressive Ag reement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) should be advanced for Asia to remain compet itive in global value chains and to replace the US to become the global consumer mar ket.

To reduce the dollar dependency, a multi-currency c learing system must be introduced for energy trade, in particular, for crude oil and liquefied natural gas as currency and energy are the lifeblood of the economy.
To strengt hen the liquidity and effectiveness of the multi-currency regime, off-shore markets bas ed on the Japanese yen and the Chinese yuan should be further developed.
Stock exchanges in the region should also be deregu lated so that foreign companies can raise capital by tapping into excessive savings that corporate and household sectors have accumulated.

While the US military cuts back involvement in the Middle East and potentially in Asia, each region, in particular, the US allies, need to take up more responsibilities to establish a new security framework not relying sole ly on the US.
When the US chooses to be “excluded,” the rest of the world should show leadership to create a new “inclusive” world order.
question: 1. What is protectionism and how does it differ from free trade?
close_book_answer: Protectionism is an economic policy that seeks to restrict imports and promote domestic industries by imposing tariffs, quotas, and other trade barriers. It differs from free trade, which advocates for the removal of trade barriers and the promotion of international trade.
Claim 1: Protectionism can lead to inefficiencies and higher prices for consumers.

Evidence: When a country imposes tariffs on imports, it increases the cost of those goods for domestic consumers. This leads to higher prices and reduces the purchasing power of consumers. Additionally, protectionism can lead to inefficiencies in domestic industries as they may become complacent due to the lack of competition.
Claim 2: Free trade promotes competition and innovation.

Evidence: When trade barriers are removed, it opens up the market to more competition, which encourages innovation and efficiency. Domestic industries are forced to become more competitive and improve their products to remain relevant in the market. This ultimately benefits consumers as they have access to better quality products at lower prices.
Claim 3: Protectionism can lead to retaliation and trade wars.

Evidence: When a country imposes trade barriers, it can lead to retaliation from other countries. This retaliation can come in the form of tariffs or other trade barriers, which can harm domestic industries that rely on exports. Additionally, protectionism can lead to trade wars between countries, which can have negative consequences for the global economy.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Protectionism can lead to inefficiencies and higher prices for consumers.
2. Free trade promotes competition and innovation.
3. Protectionism can lead to retaliation and trade wars.

4. Asia needs to rebuild international trade via promotion of regional integration and reduce dependency on the dollar.

question: 2. How has the US shifted towards protectionism and what are the reasons behind it?
close_book_answer: The US has been shifting towards protectionism in recent years, as evidenced by policies such as tariffs on imported goods and renegotiation of trade agreements. This shift can be attributed to several reasons.

Firstly, there is a belief among some policymakers and the public that free trade has led to job losses and economic decline in certain sectors of the economy. They argue that protectionist measures will help protect domestic industries and workers.

Secondly, there is a growing concern about national security and the need to protect critical industries from foreign control. This is particularly relevant in industries such as technology and telecommunications, where foreign ownership could pose a threat to national security.

Lastly, there is a sense of nationalism and a desire to promote American interests above all else. This has led to a rejection of multilateral trade agreements and a preference for bilateral deals that prioritize American interests.

However, it is important to note that protectionist policies can have negative consequences, such as higher prices for consumers and retaliation from trading partners. It is crucial for policymakers to carefully weigh the potential benefits and drawbacks of protectionism before implementing such policies.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The US has been shifting towards protectionism in recent years through policies such as tariffs and renegotiation of trade agreements.

2. Reasons for this shift include a belief that free trade has led to job losses and economic decline, a growing concern about national security, and a sense of nationalism and desire to promote American interests.
3. Protectionist policies can have negative consequences such as higher prices for consumers and retaliation from trading partners.
4. Policymakers need to carefully weigh the potential benefits and drawbacks of protectionism before implementing such policies.

question: 3. What are the challenges faced by the world due to the rise of protectionism and how can they be addressed?
close_book_answer: The rise of protectionism has become a major challenge for the world, as it has led to an increase in trade barriers and tariffs, hindering international trade. This has resulted in negative consequences such as reduced economic growth, increased inflation, and job losses. In order to address these challenges, several measures can be taken.

Firstly, it is important for countries to engage in dialogue and negotiations to resolve trade disputes and prevent the escalation of protectionist policies. The World Trade Organization (WTO) can play a vital role in facilitating such discussions and ensuring fair trade practices. Additionally, countries can explore the option of regional trade agreements, which can help to reduce trade barriers and increase cooperation.

Secondly, governments can focus on investing in education and training programs to help workers adapt to the changing global economy. This can include providing support for retraining and upskilling, as well as promoting entrepreneurship and innovation.

Lastly, it is important to address the root causes of protectionism, which often stem from domestic political pressures and economic concerns. Governments can work to address these issues by promoting inclusive economic growth, reducing income inequality, and providing social safety nets for those affected by globalization.

In conclusion, the rise of protectionism poses significant challenges for the world, but these can be addressed through dialogue and negotiation, investment in education and training, and addressing the underlying causes of protectionist policies. It is important for countries to work together to promote fair and open trade practices, while also ensuring that the benefits of globalization are shared more equitably.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Engage in dialogue and negotiations to resolve trade disputes and prevent escalation of protectionist policies.
2. Invest in education and training programs to help workers adapt to the changing global economy.
3. Address the root causes of protectionism, such as domestic political pressures and economic concerns.
4. Promote inclusive economic growth, reduce income inequality, and provide social safety nets for those affected by globalization.
5. Work together to promote fair and open trade practices and ensure that the benefits of globalization are shared more equitably.

question: 4. How can Asia respond to the protectionist policies of the US and what measures can be taken to reduce dependency on the dollar?
close_book_answer: Asia can respond to the protectionist policies of the US by diversifying its trade partners and increasing regional integration. Firstly, Asian countries can reduce their reliance on the US market by expanding their trade relations with other countries, such as the European Union, Africa, and Latin America. This will not only reduce their vulnerability to US protectionism but also increase their bargaining power in negotiations with the US. Secondly, Asian countries can deepen regional integration by strengthening existing trade agreements, such as the ASEAN Free Trade Area and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, and by creating new ones. This will promote intra-regional trade and investment, reduce transaction costs, and enhance the competitiveness of Asian economies.

In addition, measures can be taken to reduce dependency on the dollar. One way is to promote the use of local currencies in regional trade and investment. This can be done by establishing currency swap agreements between central banks, encouraging the use of local currencies in cross-border transactions, and creating a regional currency. By reducing the need for dollars in regional trade, Asian countries can minimize their exposure to US monetary policy and exchange rate fluctuations. Another way is to increase the use of alternative payment systems, such as digital currencies and blockchain technology. These systems offer faster, cheaper, and more secure transactions than traditional banking systems, and can facilitate cross-border trade and investment without the need for intermediaries.

Overall, Asia can respond to the protectionist policies of the US and reduce dependency on the dollar by diversifying trade partners, increasing regional integration, promoting local currencies, and adopting alternative payment systems. These measures will not only enhance the resilience of Asian economies but also contribute to the development of a more balanced and sustainable global economic system.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Asia can respond to US protectionist policies by diversifying trade partners.
2. Deepening regional integration can reduce vulnerability to US protectionism.
3. Promoting the use of local currencies can reduce dependency on the dollar.
4. Increasing the use of alternative payment systems can facilitate cross-border trade and investment.
5. These measures will enhance the resilience of Asian economies and contribute to a more balanced and sustainable global economic system.

question: 5. What are the potential consequences of a shift towards protectionism on global value chains and the world economy as a whole?
close_book_answer: The potential consequences of a shift towards protectionism on global value chains and the world economy as a whole can be devastating. Firstly, protectionism can lead to a decrease in international trade, which can result in a decline in the efficiency of global value chains. This can lead to a decrease in productivity and innovation, as companies are unable to take advantage of economies of scale and specialization. For example, if a country imposes tariffs on imported goods, it may become more expensive for companies to import the necessary inputs for their production processes, leading to a decrease in productivity and a decrease in the competitiveness of the industry.

Secondly, protectionism can lead to a decrease in foreign investment, which can result in a decline in the growth of the world economy. This is because foreign investment is often used to finance new projects and expand existing businesses, which can lead to job creation and economic growth. However, if countries become more protectionist, foreign investors may be discouraged from investing in these countries, leading to a decrease in economic growth and a decrease in job creation.

Finally, protectionism can lead to an increase in geopolitical tensions, which can have negative consequences for the world economy. This is because protectionist policies can be seen as a threat to other countries, leading to retaliatory measures and potentially leading to a trade war. This can result in a decrease in international cooperation and an increase in political tensions, which can lead to a decrease in economic growth and a decrease in global stability.

In conclusion, a shift towards protectionism can have negative consequences for global value chains and the world economy as a whole. It can lead to a decrease in international trade, a decrease in foreign investment, and an increase in geopolitical tensions, all of which can have negative consequences for economic growth and global stability. Therefore, it is important for countries to work together to promote free trade and open markets, which can lead to increased efficiency, innovation, and economic growth.
